Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Workshops to Facilitate Engineering Research Related to 2011 Tohoku-Kanto Earthquake and Tsunami

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration: The Tohoku-Kanto earthquake of March 9, 2011 and the tsunami that followed it, though unfortunately devastating, are very unique events of unparalleled scientific and engineering interest. This earthquake has caused extensive damage to built environment, yet there are examples of structures that have survived the strong shaking. Apparently, Japanese researchers have already collected some information about the damaged and undamaged structures and are willing to share this information with their US counterparts. Much can be learnt from further in-depth analysis of this information to understand the causes of failures and survivals of these structures with the objective of preventing this from happening in future events. This project will support the travel to Japan of a team of researchers to enable them to meet with Japanese engineers and researchers to gather data and information about the damage caused by this earthquake and tsunami that can be shared with US researchers. The team will hold workshops and meetings with Japanese researchers to gather information about what data of research interest is available, and disseminate this information to the wider research community in the US through webcast seminars, Webex-type workshops, and meetings. This is expected to lead to future international research collaborations between the US and Japanese researchers for in-depth scientific investigations about the performance of the built environment during strong earthquakes, with the final objective of mitigating the impact of such mega-events and disasters.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The March 2011 East Japan Earthquake was one of the largest seismic events in the past century, resulting in more than 15,000 casualties and hundreds of billions of dollars in damage.  Damages due to the earthquake and subsequent tsunami are tragic, but information on their effects is of great value to the scientific and engineering disciplines working to understand mitigate the risks associated with natural disasters.  At the invitation of the Science Council of Japan, a small team of U.S. investigators was assembled quickly following the earthquake to join a team of Japanese researchers to inspect the heavily damaged areas in and around Sendai, Japan. This was the first team from the U.S. to inspect this region.  The U.S. team included engineering researchers with expertise in geomechanics, tsunami, buildings, infrastructure and fire. The team reported back to NSF, and to the U.S. research community and the public, regarding (1) its findings on the effects of the earthquake, aftershocks, and tsunami, (2) on the needs for quickly collecting perishable data to support subsequent scientific and engineering investigations, and (3) resources available in Japan to support gathering of that information.

The joint reconnaissance team arranged for and participated in several major briefing, including ones with the Tokyo Institute of Technology (Center for Urban Earthquake Engineering), Japanese Society of Civil Engineers, Japan Association for Earthquake Engineering, the Architectural Institute of Japan, the Ports and Airport Research Institute and the University of Tohoku.  The team visited a large number of building sites in and around Sendai where various types of building and soil damages were observed. The team visited Ichinoseki, north of Sendai, where the largest ground acceleration (about 2.9g) was recorded during the earthquake. The team also visited the coastal plane area near Sendai (where there was extensive tsunami damage to ports and to housing near the seashore), and several coastal cities (including Rikuzentakada, Kesennuma and Onagawa) that suffered major damage due to tsunami. In Tokyo, team members visited building sites where relatively little damage was observed, and several manmade islands where considerable liquefaction and damage due to ground settlement and spreading were observed.

A brief but thorough report was prepared by the team immediately upon return to the U.S.  This report was widely disseminated on-line to help the earthquake engineering research community prepare proposals for submission to NSFs RAPID program.  The reconnaissance team also held a public seminar within ten days of its return from Japan.  More than 150 people attended in person, with 300 more viewers on line. ?The areas suggested for future research included: (1) The tsunami and its effects; (2) The effects of the earthquake and tsunami on Japanese infrastructure, with particular emphasis on nuclear power plants, infrastructure (electricity, rail and highway systems, etc.); (3) The cause and effects of the wide spread liquefaction in coastal and river regions throughout Japan; and (?4) The effect of ground shaking on structures (why was it so light, why tall buildings responded so violently, and how did high performance system behave in the earthquake).

A series of workshops were held after NSF announced the RAPID awards. These workshops helped the various research teams learn about each other’s objectives and plans and where possible coordinate activities and share data.
